concept.title: Use segments with multiple containers
concept.shortdesc: Describes several methods of combining segment containers and using them in reporting.

section.title: Define containers in both the Include and Exclude canvasses
section.p: When using both the Include and Exclude canvas, you can obtain a much more detailed set of data to report against. Data is processed using the following sequence:

ol.li: Calculate what data is included within the Include container. Any data that does not match this canvas is ignored in the segmented report.
Apply the exclude canvas rules to the remaining data. Any data that matches these rules is ignored in the segmented report.
The remaining data (that matches the Include canvas and does not match anything in the exclude canvas) is included in the resulting report.

section.title: Define multiple containers within a single canvas
section.p:
When dragging multiple segments adjacent to each other, they are considered an "or" statement. All containers in the canvas are reviewed against all data, and any data that matches any of the containers is included in reporting. For example:
Visit container where Country equals United States
Visit container where an order occurred

ol.li: This segment would first look at your entire data and pull in all visits within the United States.
It would then look at all your data once again, this time searching to see if any image requests contained an order.
These two sets of data are then included in reporting.

section.title: Nest containers within each other
section.p: When creating segment containers within other containers, you are in essence creating a segment within a segment. The following logic is used with nested containers:

ol.li: Determine what data is included using the outermost container. Any data that does not match this outer rule is discarded in the segmented report.
Apply the nested rule to the remaining data. The nested rule does NOT apply to any hits that the first rule throws out.
Repeat until all nested container rules have been calculated. The remaining data is then included in the resulting report.
